Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Multi-Dimensional Structuring, Summarizing and Mining of Social Media Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Various kinds of social media have impacted billions of users on their ways of obtaining and sharing information across the globe. This creates great opportunities but also poses tremendous challenges on understanding, summarizing, and mining of such data due to its huge volume as well as dynamic and unstructured nature of its text contents. In response to such challenges, this project focuses on text-based social media, proposes a multi-dimensional data structuring approach, which mines unstructured social media data to uncover its hidden multi-dimensional structures. The project investigates principle, methodologies and algorithms for social media structuring, summarizing and mining, and develops effective and scalable technology for multi-dimensional social media data analysis. The principles and methodologies developed in this study can be extended to scalable and multi-dimensional analysis of other kinds of massive unstructured data as well.

To conduct effective multi-dimensional social media structuring, this project develops a distant supervision-based methodology with minimal effort of human curation and labeling. It takes data in Wikipedia, Freebase, or other knowledge-bases as references, integrates social media data with the corresponding news or other relevant documents, conducts phrase mining, entity and event discovery and typing, and uncover critical aspects, attributes, and values associated with such entities and events from social media. By organizing social media data in a structured way, massive social media can be summarizing effectively in a context-aware semantic OLAP (online analytical processing) framework and can be analyzed systematically under a general multi-dimensional social media querying and mining framework for many tasks, such as modeling behavioral patterns and uncovering bursty events and detecting social frauds or anomalies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates new principles and methodologies and develops scalable and effective algorithms for multi-dimensional structuring, summarization, and mining of social media data.  Various kinds of social media have impacted billions of users on their ways of obtaining and sharing information across the globe.   This creates great opportunities but also poses tremendous challenges on understanding, summarizing, and mining of such data due to its huge volume as well as dynamic and unstructured nature of its text contents.   In response to such challenges, this project focuses on text-based social media, proposes a multi-dimensional data structuring approach, which mines unstructured social media data to uncover its hidden multi-dimensional structures.   The principles and methodologies developed in this study can be extended to scalable and multi-dimensional analysis of other kinds of massive unstructured, text-rich data as well.

To conduct effective multi-dimensional social media structuring, this project develops a weakly or distantly supervised methodology with minimal effort of human curation and labeling.   It takes data in Wikipedia or other knowledge bases as references, integrates social media data with the corresponding news or other relevant documents, conducts phrase mining, text embedding, entity and event discovery and typing, and uncover critical aspects, attributes, and values associated with such entities and events from social media.  By organizing social media data in a structured way, massive social media data can be summarizing effectively in a context aware semantic OLAP (online analytical processing) framework and can be analyzed systematically under a general multi-dimensional social media querying and mining framework for many tasks, including discriminative topic mining, event discovery, sentiment analysis, and detecting text outliers or social anomalies.

In this project, we have proposed a set of effective approaches for multi-dimensional structuring and mining text-intensive social media.  Multi-dimensional structuring involves integrating social media data with news, Wikipedia, and other knowledge base data, conducting phrase mining, spherical text embedding, weakly supervised text embedding, discriminative topic mining, entity/event discovery and typing, text classification, text outlier analysis, aspect-based sentiment analysis, and uncovering aspects associated with such entities and events.  Organizing massive social media data in a conceptually structured way facilitates understand and summarize social media information effectively, support context aware semantic OLAP, facilitate multi-dimensional mining of social media data.

This project has generated a set of innovative and effective data mining methods, with three research monographs and over 100 research papers published in scientific journals and international conferences (with two won research paper awards).  The most notable methods developed include (1) joint spherical text embedding, JoSE (NeurIPS?19); (2) weakly supervised text embedding for category-guided topic mining (CaTE) (WWW?20) and hierarchical topic mining (JoSH) (KDD?20); (3) weakly supervised phrase mining: AutoPhase (TKDE?18) and UCPhrase (KDD?21); (4) weakly supervised text classification: WeSTClass (CIKM?18), WeSHClass (AAAI?19), LotClass (EMNLP?20), TaxoClass (NAACL?21); (5) entity/relational extraction and typing: ClusType (KDD?16), CoType (WWW?17), AutoNER (EMNLP?18), PENNER (IBBM?18); (6) automated taxonomy construction and refinement: SetExpan (ECMLPKDD?18), HiExpan (KDD?18), TaxoGen (KDD?18), NetTaxo (WWW?20), TaxoExpan (WWW?20); and (7) text summarization,  sentiment analysis and evidence mining: SumDOCS (SDM?21), JASEN (EMNLP?20), EvidenceMiner (ACL?20).

The project has trained a good number of young researchers, with 10 PhD students graduated (3 of them are female PhDs) and three PhDs received 2018, 2019 and 2020 ACM SIGKDD Dissertation Award or Runner-Ups. Four new PhDs joined U.S. universities as assistant professors at USC, Georgia Tech, UC San Diego, and Emory University respectively.   Most of the other PhD graduates joined major U.S. industry including Google Research, Google, and Facebook. The research has generated also two massive online courses, 6 demo-systems, 12 conference tutorials, and more than 30 keynote/invited speeches in international conferences, workshops and industry firms.

The progress of the project and the research results are also disseminated via the project Web site: http://hanj.cs.illinois.edu/projs/social_media.htm.
